commit_message:
Test multi-cast messaging between VMs.

Test multi-cast messages are delivered bewteen two VMs
using IPv4 through the same tenant network.

This new test scenario requires advanced image to be run as
it needs to run python3 scripts and python3 is not available
on Cirros.

Co-authored-by: Slawek Kaplonski <skaplons@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Idd1589adbff6e556290f43fabbb8a23737a34adf

commit_message:
Remove RetryFilter from config

Since Ic0a03e89903bf925638fa26cca3dac7db710dca3 RetryFilter has been
deprecated. So we should not enable the RetryFilter on our tests.

Change-Id: I48c2c4d0714f582af8948dc88b48df1c2c62fcd2

commit_message:
Re-add Infortrend Cinder volume driver

The Infortrend driver was removed due to
not meet the CI requirements.
Now we have fixed the CI issues.

Change-Id: I60416fa93a4990a7a07ac662c448335289ba7417
Implements: blueprint readd-infortrend-driver

subject: Support enforcing node allocatable and QoS
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6484, 'name': 'Feilong Wang', 'email': 'hustemb@gmail.com', 'username': 'flwang'}, {'_account_id': 7822, 'name': 'Chris Hoge (not involved in upstream development)', 'email': 'chris@hogepodge.com', 'username': 'hogepodge'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 28022, 'name': 'Bharat Kunwar', 'email': 'brtknr@bath.edu', 'username': 'brtknr'}, {'_account_id': 29425, 'name': 'Diogo Guerra', 'email': 'diogo.filipe.tomas.guerra@cern.ch', 'username': 'dioguerra'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 16006, 'date': '2019-06-17 14:56:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-06-25 13:45:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-07-04 01:05:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 29425, 'date': '2019-07-16 08:18:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I feel that this enforcement should be optional, and not default.
And if you are planning to do this, i would also require you to add default values for the resources on 

Kube Reserver and System Reserved CPU & Memory

https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/reserve-compute-resources/'}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2019-07-25 19:00:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I can see the argument for making this configurable to start. Would it make sense to make it configurable/optional to preserve behavior for this release, then switch to activated for the next release?'}, {'account_id': 16006, 'date': '2019-07-25 21:57:24.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-17 14:56:56.000000000', 'message': 'Support enforcing node allocatable and QoS

Magnum supports cgroups which is nice but some features are
required to avoid pods to consume all the resources of a nodes.

Options added to masters and nodes:

  --cgroups-per-qos=true --enforce-node-allocatable=pods

Change-Id: I284718358865c4dcac06243c3116fd5868623439
Story: 2005903
Task: 33765
'}]
commit_message:
Support enforcing node allocatable and QoS

Magnum supports cgroups which is nice but some features are
required to avoid pods to consume all the resources of a nodes.

Options added to masters and nodes:

  --cgroups-per-qos=true --enforce-node-allocatable=pods

Change-Id: I284718358865c4dcac06243c3116fd5868623439
Story: 2005903
Task: 33765

subject: Add "--allow_privileged=true" to kube-apiserver

commit_message:
Add "--allow_privileged=true" to kube-apiserver

If --allow_privileged=true is not set on the kube-apiserver argument
list then the deployment will fail because of policy issue during
Calico and auto-healing setup.

Change-Id: Ib1bc720dcc13f8ad10e83b30f1ab96ad254df83c
Story: #2006252
Task: #35867

commit_message:
Fix os-collect-config path in heat-container-agent

In launch script, absolute path /usr/bin/os-collect-config is
not working anymore which prevent heat-container-agent to start
properly.

Change-Id: I95c84c53d8c1220d2f2bad08b8f1c895b303a095
Story: #2006268
Task: #35963

commit_message:
heat-agent: Do not use absolute path

In a recent version of fedora base and
python/pip that comes with it, pip installed
pkgs put their binaries in /usr/local/bin
instead of /usr/bin. Since the lanuch script is
a bash script we do not have to use the absolute
path.

Change-Id: I9f31d047fe538114136d2199b447e3fe8248aa8c
Signed-off-by: Spyros Trigazis <spyridon.trigazis@cern.ch>

[{'created': '2019-07-22 20:13:43.000000000', 'message': "Enhance the config_template comment parser

The config_template comment parser will now respect all comments in
INI files, as they are written. This will ensure spacing, paragraphs,
and other comments bits that may be in an INI file remain intact,
even when overrideing options and sections. With this feature we'll
now be able to insert options in OSLO config generated files without
truncating or making a mess of the file structure.

This is an internal enhancement and requires no change from the
operator or from within any ansible task.

Change-Id: Ia6cdc215c35fa9ac45b718c211616a9887a74e37
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Enhance the config_template comment parser

The config_template comment parser will now respect all comments in
INI files, as they are written. This will ensure spacing, paragraphs,
and other comments bits that may be in an INI file remain intact,
even when overriding options and sections. With this feature we'll
now be able to insert options in OSLO config generated files without
truncating or making a mess of the file structure.

This is an internal enhancement and requires no change from the
operator or from within any ansible task. To ensure enhanced comments
are working, new tests have been added which will run though all of
the `config_template` INI file functions using a mock service file.
Existing tests for the old comment structure has been removed.
This includes tests that were running redundant tasks for file
diffs or expected the only style, merged, comment layout. All of the
tests have been broken out into descriptive task files. This was
largely done for readability. It was difficult to see what tests
we had and how I needed to extend them to test the enhanced comments
functionality given the INI type tests were all thoughout the
`tests/test-common-tasks.yml`. Now that the files have been broken
out developers will easily be able to audit our tests making it
simple to extend.

Change-Id: Ia6cdc215c35fa9ac45b718c211616a9887a74e37
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-22 08:37:58.000000000', 'message': 'Add tcp-check connect port line to haproxy redis stanza

When https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1677420 will be merged
in haproxy (via haproxy-1.5.18-9.el7.x86_64) our redis backend will stop
working because the fix around tcp-check is now more correct and
according to the haproxy doc a tcp-check sections *must* start with
tcp-check connect first. From
http://cbonte.github.io/haproxy-dconv/1.5/configuration.html#4-tcp-check%20connect
:
"""
When there are no TCP port configured on the server line neither server port
directive, then the 'tcp-check connect port <port>' must be the first step
of the sequence.
"""

Change-Id: I261eb30b52a3baee3b0e6d47e8f32f3c579930bf
Co-Authored-By: Luca Miccini <lmiccini@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1837086
'}]
commit_message:
Add tcp-check connect port line to haproxy redis stanza

When https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1677420 will be merged
in haproxy (via haproxy-1.5.18-9.el7.x86_64) our redis backend will stop
working because the fix around tcp-check is now more correct and
according to the haproxy doc a tcp-check sections *must* start with
tcp-check connect first. From
http://cbonte.github.io/haproxy-dconv/1.5/configuration.html#4-tcp-check%20connect
:
"""
When there are no TCP port configured on the server line neither server port
directive, then the 'tcp-check connect port <port>' must be the first step
of the sequence.
"""

Change-Id: I261eb30b52a3baee3b0e6d47e8f32f3c579930bf
Co-Authored-By: Luca Miccini <lmiccini@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1837086

commit_message:
Untyped vol to default vol type

This spec proposes to use default volume type instead of
allowing users to create untyped volumes.

Change-Id: Ib5050f5b23300414a7903b48917460639e12aab7
Partial-Implements: blueprint untyped-volumes-default-volume-type

Thanks for addressing my comments.  This makes more sense to me now.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-07-12 13:50:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I'm OK with the general direction, just have a few concerns about the proposal.

(1) The nova changes-since query filter is documented to included deleted servers in the response.  If we don't want to do that, I don't think we should use 'changes-since' as the query string token for this function because it will be confusing to users.

(2) Instead of introducing changes-since and changed-prior-to, why not use created_at and updated_at with time comparison operators?  Glance does something like this [0].  It might be more flexible for operators, and would just be a new filter on the current API response (so there'd be no expectation that the volume-list response would contain a superset of the current response).

(If you don't like suggestion (2), you can explain why it's not a good idea in the Alternatives section of your spec.)

[0] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/image/v2/?expanded=list-images-detail#v2-comparison-ops"}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2019-07-17 15:31:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: -Code-Review

I think Brian's comments are good.  We are running short on time to get this in.  Wanghao, can you respond to the comments?"}, {'account_id': 8846, 'date': '2019-07-19 07:52:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

@Brian, TBH,  we are entangled in the name of the filter for a while, at first we want to keep consistent with other projects like Nova. But as you said, it also may bring some confusion to users.  I like the Glance did, it will expand the functions that we can filter,  created_at or updated_at. So I'm ok with that. I will update the spec and see others' comments."}, {'account_id': 8846, 'date': '2019-07-19 08:39:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-07-23 21:30:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

This looks good to me.  I'm going to ask around whether there may be a problem with using a semicolon as the separator for a duration (I don't think so, and it's an implementation detail anyway)."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-07-24 10:41:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

You probably want ','. ';' won't work, see within."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-07-24 13:19:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

@Chris: thanks for the input.

@wanghao: please make the change suggested by Chris.  Other than that, I'm fine with this proposal."}, {'account_id': 8846, 'date': '2019-07-25 01:41:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8846, 'date': '2019-07-25 01:43:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-07-25 20:09:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

This looks good to me.'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2019-07-25 20:19:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

This looks good to me now.  Thanks for addressing the comments.'}]

commit_message:
Update the spec of filtering by time comparison operators for Train

This BP propose to support users can query resources by specifying the time
comparison operators along with created_at or updated_at fields,
and cinder will return all which match the condition.

Will add six time comparison operators in querying API.
"volumes/detail?updated_at=gt:2016-01-01T01:00:00,lt:2016-12-01T01:00:00"

Change-Id: Ia041bf4e1205cdb9c3b94af6566e4850fb54eecc

[{'created': '2019-05-16 22:08:08.000000000', 'message': 'Add nosec in get_free_segmentation_id function

pep8 job fails due to bandit check with an error:
    [B311:blacklist] Standard pseudo-random generators are not suitable 
    for security/cryptographic purposes.

But using the standard random function in the get_free_segmentation_id 
function is suitable, so adding #nosec comment should unbblock the gate.

Change-Id: Iad8e376c503a32300b3e0b504f47a0c81e53a7a8
(cherry picked from commit 4ae79ba52b15eb715a23070455547983ed0790da)
'}]
commit_message:
Add nosec in get_free_segmentation_id function

pep8 job fails due to bandit check with an error:
    [B311:blacklist] Standard pseudo-random generators are not suitable 
    for security/cryptographic purposes.

But using the standard random function in the get_free_segmentation_id 
function is suitable, so adding #nosec comment should unbblock the gate.

Change-Id: Iad8e376c503a32300b3e0b504f47a0c81e53a7a8
(cherry picked from commit 4ae79ba52b15eb715a23070455547983ed0790da)

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I7766232891d5cbef082e5c55b824161ad45c09d3

The only user for this kwarg was unit tests testing the kwarg.

commit_message:
Spec for the Cinder part of Image Encryption

We want to propose Image Encryption for Openstack, which would affect Cinder,
but also Nova and Glance. This spec contains the details of the Cinder part
for the Image Encryption. The transformations from image to volume and from
volume to image are discussed.

Change-Id: Ib2cd599cbc102bbc123ab88bc4813aca3d81ba10
Co-Authored-By: Markus Hentsch <markus.hentsch@secustack.com>

the depends-on for more information on the rationale.

Change-Id: I509ded97085fbae5a0cc55fe66f6e30e638b72bc
'}, {'created': '2019-07-25 15:20:09.000000000', 'message': 'Use integrated-gate-placement zuul template

The integrated-gate-placement adds the tempest-integrated-placement
and grenade-py3 jobs. tempest-integrated-placement runs a subset of
tempest tests which are relevant for placement, e.g. it does not
run keystone tests.

The integrated-gate-py3 template is replaced by this change. It
specified the tempest-full-py3, meaning many tests not relevant
to placement were run.

See the depends-on for more information on the rationale.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/669309
Change-Id: I509ded97085fbae5a0cc55fe66f6e30e638b72bc
'}]
commit_message:
Use integrated-gate-placement zuul template

The integrated-gate-placement adds the tempest-integrated-placement
and grenade-py3 jobs. tempest-integrated-placement runs a subset of
tempest tests which are relevant for placement, e.g. it does not
run keystone tests.

The integrated-gate-py3 template is replaced by this change. It
specified the tempest-full-py3, meaning many tests not relevant
to placement were run.

See the depends-on for more information on the rationale.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/669309

commit_message:
Add kolla-ansible to zuul job dependencies

This means we can pull in the job from other repositories without
explicitly adding the dependency on kolla-ansible in that project.

Change-Id: Ia7e4294508e6d445638c176359a939af32fdfb12
(cherry picked from commit 8d523dabd8646e14f7eb671766091a0ce35de773)

[{'created': '2019-06-10 20:24:49.000000000', 'message': 'Cap the maximum number of rpc workers

Currently, there is only one process for all
rabbitmq processing. This is not enough and
causes systems to get clogged up.

Change-Id: Ie4823ed85582d3056c7837e3a8a4e7a53fac653c
'}]
commit_message:
Cap the maximum number of rpc workers

Currently, there is only one process for all
rabbitmq processing. This is not enough and
causes systems to get clogged up.

Change-Id: Ie4823ed85582d3056c7837e3a8a4e7a53fac653c

commit_message:
Remove duplicated irrelevant-files for sanity check

This commit removes duplicated irrelevant-files for sanity-check in the
job definition. We have the same entries in the later. So we can remove
the redundancy.

Change-Id: I11e2054758fb9d4292e7cc64b58017c3e462c939

uses global upper-constraints.txt only from Rocky,
job openstack-tox-py27 tries to install Sphinx 2.0.1 and fails [1] with:

 Downloading http://mirror.iad.rax.openstack.org/wheel/ubuntu-16.04-x86_64/sphinx/Sphinx-2.0.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl (3.2MB)

Note: .[oslo.config] could be removed as the packages will be installed

commit_message:
Use upper constraints

Sphinx 2.0.0 dropped python 2.7 and 3.4 support. Because osprofiler
uses global upper-constraints.txt only from Rocky,
job openstack-tox-py27 tries to install Sphinx 2.0.1 and fails [1] with:

 Downloading http://mirror.iad.rax.openstack.org/wheel/ubuntu-16.04-x86_64/sphinx/Sphinx-2.0.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl (3.2MB)
 ERROR: Sphinx requires Python '>=3.5' but the running Python is 2.7.12

Note: .[oslo.config] could be removed as the packages will be installed
perfectly and constrained without this and it breaks installation if
upper-constraints.txt is used anyway.

Note: patch adjusted to Ocata, and in Ocata this is needed due to
GitPython as it dropped support for python 2.7

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/periodic-stable/opendev.org/openstack/osprofiler/stable/queens/openstack-tox-py27/3d469d3/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-05-10_06_10_56_192617

Change-Id: Ife6bcaca347d914cb1fc7e2fe71665ea5c93ca80
(cherry picked from commit eff57e09b55aaf1f00b01c289526ceddefdf25d9)
(cherry picked from commit bfe78732b9991f11986099cd9cfa1b5afd94e0a3)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-24 12:06:01.000000000', 'message': 'Fix cleanup of persistence tests

Cinderlib is designed to only have 1 persitent plugin loaded through
the whole life of the application, so our unit tests have to work around
this by cleaning things up manually, which they are not doing correctly.

Current code runs fine because test_dbms.py goes before test_memory.py,
but if we rename the test_memory.py to test_a.py then we'll start seing
"IndexError: list index out of range" errors.

There are 2 issues with the current code:

- We are not cleaning up properly after the memory persistence test
  because we are changing instance attributes instead of the class
  attributes.  We resolve this calling the clear method instead.

- We are not taking into account that the memory persistency plugin
  changes some of the OVO methods, so we need to restore them after
  the tests.

Change-Id: I29847f7a8de49625882145c3eff7983ff8d01265
'}]
commit_message:
Fix cleanup of persistence tests

Cinderlib is designed to only have 1 persitent plugin loaded through
the whole life of the application, so our unit tests have to work around
this by cleaning things up manually, which they are not doing correctly.

Current code runs fine because test_dbms.py goes before test_memory.py,
but if we rename the test_memory.py to test_a.py then we'll start seing
"IndexError: list index out of range" errors.

There are 2 issues with the current code:

- We are not cleaning up properly after the memory persistence test
  because we are changing instance attributes instead of the class
  attributes.  We resolve this calling the clear method instead.

- We are not taking into account that the memory persistency plugin
  changes some of the OVO methods, so we need to restore them after
  the tests.

Change-Id: I29847f7a8de49625882145c3eff7983ff8d01265

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-22 16:53:48.000000000', 'message': "Remove 'nova.virt.driver.ComputeDriver.estimate_instance_overhead'

As discussed in change I2936ce8cb293dc80e1a426094fdae6e675461470, there
are alternatives ways to describe instance overhead that can and should
be used. Remove the final caller of this driver function, which in turn
allows us to remove all implementations and the definition from the base
driver class.

Change-Id: I033e8269194de54432079cbc970431e3dcea7ce5
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-07-23 10:44:06.000000000', 'message': "Remove 'nova.virt.driver.ComputeDriver.estimate_instance_overhead'

With the removal of the Core, Ram and Disk filters in change
I8a0d332877fbb9794700081e7954f2501b7e7c09, there's now only a single
caller for the 'estimate_instance_overhead' function. This call results
in the 'memory_mb_used', 'local_gb_used', 'vcpus_used', 'free_ram_mb'
and 'free_disk_gb' fields of a compute nodes 'ComputeNode' object being
modified when calculating usage as part of the resource tracker.
However, in most cases these fields aren't actually used for anything
except logging, the 'os-hypervisors' API, and a path that triggers when
a virt driver doesn't implement the 'update_provider_tree' interface.
Support for virt drivers that don't implement the 'update_provider_tree'
interface was deprecated in I1eae47bce08f6292d38e893a2122289bcd6f4b58
and is no longer used by any of the in-tree drivers. As a result, the
implementations of the 'estimate_instance_overhead' function for these
drivers can be removed, with an eye on removing the interface entirely
once the drivers are required to implement 'update_provider_tree'.

Change-Id: I033e8269194de54432079cbc970431e3dcea7ce5
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-07-23 13:36:19.000000000', 'message': "Remove 'nova.virt.driver.ComputeDriver.estimate_instance_overhead'

caller for the 'estimate_instance_overhead' function. This call results
in the 'memory_mb_used', 'local_gb_used', 'vcpus_used', 'free_ram_mb'
and 'free_disk_gb' fields of a compute nodes 'ComputeNode' object being
modified when calculating usage as part of the resource tracker.
However, in most cases these fields aren't actually used for anything
except logging, the 'os-hypervisors' API, and a path that triggers when
a virt driver doesn't implement the 'update_provider_tree' interface.
Support for virt drivers that don't implement the 'update_provider_tree'
interface was deprecated in I1eae47bce08f6292d38e893a2122289bcd6f4b58
and is no longer used by any of the in-tree drivers. As a result, the
implementations of the 'estimate_instance_overhead' function for these
drivers can be removed, with an eye on removing the interface entirely
once the drivers are required to implement 'update_provider_tree'.

Change-Id: I033e8269194de54432079cbc970431e3dcea7ce5
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-07-23 14:49:51.000000000', 'message': "Remove 'nova.virt.driver.ComputeDriver.estimate_instance_overhead'

With the removal of the Core, Ram and Disk filters in change
I8a0d332877fbb9794700081e7954f2501b7e7c09, there's now only a single
caller for the 'estimate_instance_overhead' function. This call results
in the 'memory_mb_used', 'local_gb_used', 'vcpus_used', 'free_ram_mb'
and 'free_disk_gb' fields of a compute nodes 'ComputeNode' object being
modified when calculating usage as part of the resource tracker.
However, in most cases these fields aren't actually used for anything
except logging, the 'os-hypervisors' API, and a path that triggers when
a virt driver doesn't implement the 'update_provider_tree' interface.
Support for virt drivers that don't implement the 'update_provider_tree'
interface was deprecated in I1eae47bce08f6292d38e893a2122289bcd6f4b58
and is no longer used by any of the in-tree drivers. As a result, the
implementations of the 'estimate_instance_overhead' function for these
drivers can be removed, with an eye on removing the interface entirely
once the drivers are required to implement 'update_provider_tree'.

Change-Id: I033e8269194de54432079cbc970431e3dcea7ce5
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-07-24 15:29:42.000000000', 'message': "Remove 'nova.virt.driver.ComputeDriver.estimate_instance_overhead'

With the removal of the Core, Ram and Disk filters in change
I8a0d332877fbb9794700081e7954f2501b7e7c09, there's now only a single
caller for the 'estimate_instance_overhead' function. This call results
in the 'memory_mb_used', 'local_gb_used', 'vcpus_used', 'free_ram_mb'
and 'free_disk_gb' fields of a compute nodes 'ComputeNode' object being
modified when calculating usage as part of the resource tracker to
include driver-specific overhead. However, these fields are no longer
used for for anything except logging and the 'os-hypervisors' API. Since
overhead is not reflected in placement (and therefore the scheduler),
reporting them as part of the various usage values for both logging and
that API is actually a bit of a lie and is likely to cause confusion
among users. Remove the whole thing and make our logs and the
'os-hypervisors' API better match what's stored in placement.

Change-Id: I033e8269194de54432079cbc970431e3dcea7ce5
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Remove 'nova.virt.driver.ComputeDriver.estimate_instance_overhead'

With the removal of the Core, Ram and Disk filters in change
I8a0d332877fbb9794700081e7954f2501b7e7c09, there's now only a single
caller for the 'estimate_instance_overhead' function. This call results
in the 'memory_mb_used', 'local_gb_used', 'vcpus_used', 'free_ram_mb'
and 'free_disk_gb' fields of a compute nodes 'ComputeNode' object being
modified when calculating usage as part of the resource tracker to
include driver-specific overhead. However, these fields are no longer
used for for anything except logging and the 'os-hypervisors' API. Since
overhead is not reflected in placement (and therefore the scheduler),
reporting them as part of the various usage values for both logging and
that API is actually a bit of a lie and is likely to cause confusion
among users. Remove the whole thing and make our logs and the
'os-hypervisors' API better match what's stored in placement.

Change-Id: I033e8269194de54432079cbc970431e3dcea7ce5
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2019-07-17 12:34:35.000000000', 'message': 'Replace hardcoded gather_facts:no with variable

Use a gather_facts variable to control fact gathering at the play level
instead of just the hardcoded gather_facts:no.

This allows for forcing facts to be gathered during a play if the
earlier fact gathering tasks had been skipped (such as when using
--start-at-task).

Change-Id: I2b7625baac4a09413cc50b84d2df1c00ec14b00a
(cherry picked from commit 203418529a737b5f9a26afb384ac54924ca5159b)
'}]
commit_message:
Replace hardcoded gather_facts:no with variable

Use a gather_facts variable to control fact gathering at the play level
instead of just the hardcoded gather_facts:no.

This allows for forcing facts to be gathered during a play if the
earlier fact gathering tasks had been skipped (such as when using
--start-at-task).

Change-Id: I2b7625baac4a09413cc50b84d2df1c00ec14b00a
(cherry picked from commit 203418529a737b5f9a26afb384ac54924ca5159b)

commit_message:
utils: make update_cell_database() flexible

In order to fix bug/1835037 it will be necessary to update cell
details of both cell0 and cell1.

In this commit we update the method update_cell_database() to take a
new argument which provides ability to set cell names that have to be
updated.

Related-bug: #1835037
Change-Id: I53fb879ce1fc173b7aa1e2b477b850135576a040
Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@canonical.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-19 13:56:54.000000000', 'message': 'Remove .zuul.yaml in stein to fix jobs in master

Zuul jobs in master are failing because Zuul merges the configuration
of .zuul.yaml in all branches [0]. A change in devstack [1] affected
the quoting of variables, resulting in extra quotes around the var
TEMPEST_PLUGINS. This was fixed in master by moving to a new syntax
for selecting tempest plugins [2], but the presence of the old variable
here causes conflicts. Removing the file as a workaround until the
branch is deleted [3].

References:
[0] https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/user/config.html#configuration-loading
[1] https://review.opendev.org/636078
[2] https://review.opendev.org/670229
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-July/007740.html

Change-Id: I0e7db56bb10b0e390bfd6f7d230a1bfc9faff09f
'}]
commit_message:
Remove .zuul.yaml in stein to fix jobs in master

Zuul jobs in master are failing because Zuul merges the configuration
of .zuul.yaml in all branches [0]. A change in devstack [1] affected
the quoting of variables, resulting in extra quotes around the var
TEMPEST_PLUGINS. This was fixed in master by moving to a new syntax
for selecting tempest plugins [2], but the presence of the old variable
here causes conflicts. Removing the file as a workaround until the
branch is deleted [3].

References:
[0] https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/user/config.html#configuration-loading
[1] https://review.opendev.org/636078
[2] https://review.opendev.org/670229
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-July/007740.html

Change-Id: I0e7db56bb10b0e390bfd6f7d230a1bfc9faff09f

transport and database URLs.

commit_message:
utils: workaround to update cell0's transport/database URLs

The command to update cells is curently bugged when requesting
cell0. This change workaround the problem by passing the correct
transport and database URLs.

Related-Bug: #1835037
Change-Id: If9439ec80883d74fb5d6929c6604192eff014740
Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Fix resume_guests_state_on_host_boot_enabled fact

NovaResumeGuestsStateOnHostBoot is a role parameter so we
need to get the value from there.

Change-Id: I9e13491b6f86143f507d2b56fa1eed83204418d0
Closes-Bug: 1837731

'}, {'created': '2019-07-16 07:31:01.000000000', 'message': "implement system scope for application credential

Implement system scopes, namely 'admin', 'reader', and 'member' for
the application credential API. Thus, making it consistent with other
system-scoped policy definitions.

For the application credential API, the follow policies will be enforced:

- system admin can fetch, list, lookup, and delete user's application
  credentials.
- system member and reader can only fetch, list, and lookup user's application
  credentials. Deleting a user's application credential other their own is
  strictly prohibitted.
- domain and project admins can no longer touch user's application credentials
  other their own.
- create an application credential can only be done by the owner. No one else
  can create an application credential on behalf of another user.

Test cases are added to guard the above policy changes.

Change-Id: I26ee11571b6d0f700a5fe3a62ad2e8fc7f5316fe
Closes-Bug: 1818725

commit_message:
implement system scope for application credential

Implement system scopes, namely 'admin', 'reader', and 'member' for
the application credential API. Thus, making it consistent with other
system-scoped policy definitions.

For the application credential API, the follow policies will be enforced:

- system admin can fetch, list, lookup, and delete user's application
  credentials.
- system member and reader can only fetch, list, and lookup user's application
  credentials. Deleting a user's application credential other their own is
  strictly prohibitted.
- domain and project admins can no longer touch user's application credentials
  other their own.
- domain and project readers cannot touch user's application credentials
  other their own.
- domain and project members cannot touch user's application credentials
  other their own.
- create an application credential can only be done by the owner. No one else
  can create an application credential on behalf of another user.

Test cases are added to guard the above policy changes.

Change-Id: I26ee11571b6d0f700a5fe3a62ad2e8fc7f5316fe
Closes-Bug: 1818725
Closes-Bug: 1750615

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-14 13:25:38.000000000', 'message': '[POC][DNM] Add interface kind property

- Add a new propery to LinuxInterfaceDriver that allows
  to query the kind of interface created during plug()

- Add a new property to IPDevice to allow us to identify
  the kind of the interface.

This change is required as an out of tree interface driver
which supports operations on a per-physnet basis
needs to be aware of the kind of interface an interface driver
creates in order to correlate between an interface driver
and an interface created by it.

TODO: add unit test

Change-Id: Icbdb011a639475f416ca1b98fdf3ce2f52482c7c
Partial-Bug: #1834176

This change is required as an out of tree interface driver
which supports operations on a per-physnet basis
needs to be aware of the kind of interface an interface driver
created in order to correlate between an interface driver
and an interface created by it.

Change-Id: Icbdb011a639475f416ca1b98fdf3ce2f52482c7c
Partial-Bug: #1834176
'}]
commit_message:
Add interface kind property

- Add a new property to IPDevice to allow us to identify
  the kind of the interface.

This change is required as an out of tree interface driver
which supports operations on a per-physnet basis
needs to be aware of the kind of interface an interface driver
created in order to correlate between an interface driver
and an interface created by it.

Change-Id: Icbdb011a639475f416ca1b98fdf3ce2f52482c7c
Partial-Bug: #1834176

An alternative could be to change kvm hosts to say that they support both qemu and kvm for backward compat and qemu hosts to say that they just support qemu, but I don't think that's a great idea since instances that land on kvm hosts are always accelerated by kvm. No release note issued in Rocky about this. I am agreed to revert. Thank you for remembering this change m(__)m'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-24 16:22:52.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "[libvirt] Filter hypervisor_type by virt_type"

This reverts commit eaa766ee2093c24fd61c61e52f46bdd9ff9e93d2.

The change regressed the behavior of the ImagePropertiesFilter
because existing images with hypervisor_type=QEMU, which would
match what is reported for hypervisor_type in the API for both
qemu/kvm virt_type nodes, will now get filtered out for hosts
where the configured virt_type is kvm.

Note that both the ImagePropertiesFilter docs [1] and
hypervisor_type image property docs [2] mention that for both
qemu and kvm nodes the value to use is qemu since that is the
actual hypervisor.

Presumably the change was made for a deployment with some
hosts configured with virt_type=qemu and other hosts configured
with virt_type=kvm and there were separate images with
hypervisor_type=qemu and hypervisor_type=kvm to match those hosts
for scheduler filter, but as noted this was a regression in
behavior for something that could have been achieved using
host aggregates and the AggregateImagePropertiesIsolation filter.

We could even use traits and a placement request pre-filter these
days for a more modern approach.

Also, since the API continues to report hypervisor_type=QEMU it's
doubly confusing for operators to have to configure their images
to use hypervisor_type=kvm (despite the docs).

And finally, any existing instances which have hypervisor_type=qemu
embedded in their RequestSpec can no longer be migrated to kvm
hosts without manually fixing the entries in the request_specs
table in the API DB.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/configuration/schedulers.html#imagepropertiesfilter
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/admin/useful-image-properties.html

Change-Id: I7d761dc269f8c12c4a76ba14201ccdd82a04d01d
Closes-Bug: #1837756

We could even use traits and a placement request pre-filter these

Also, since the API continues to report hypervisor_type=QEMU it's

And finally, any existing instances which have hypervisor_type=qemu

Note that this is not a clean revert because of change
I5d95bd50279a6bf903a5793ad5f3ae9d06f085f4 made in Stein.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/configuration/schedulers.html#imagepropertiesfilter

commit_message:
Revert "[libvirt] Filter hypervisor_type by virt_type"

This reverts commit eaa766ee2093c24fd61c61e52f46bdd9ff9e93d2.

The change regressed the behavior of the ImagePropertiesFilter
because existing images with hypervisor_type=QEMU, which would
match what is reported for hypervisor_type in the API for both
qemu/kvm virt_type nodes, will now get filtered out for hosts
where the configured virt_type is kvm.

Note that both the ImagePropertiesFilter docs [1] and
hypervisor_type image property docs [2] mention that for both
qemu and kvm nodes the value to use is qemu since that is the
actual hypervisor.

Presumably the change was made for a deployment with some
hosts configured with virt_type=qemu and other hosts configured
with virt_type=kvm and there were separate images with
hypervisor_type=qemu and hypervisor_type=kvm to match those hosts
for scheduler filter, but as noted this was a regression in
behavior for something that could have been achieved using
host aggregates and the AggregateImagePropertiesIsolation filter.

We could even use traits and a placement request pre-filter these
days for a more modern approach.

Also, since the API continues to report hypervisor_type=QEMU it's
doubly confusing for operators to have to configure their images
to use hypervisor_type=kvm (despite the docs).

And finally, any existing instances which have hypervisor_type=qemu
embedded in their RequestSpec can no longer be migrated to kvm
hosts without manually fixing the entries in the request_specs
table in the API DB.

Note that this is not a clean revert because of change
I5d95bd50279a6bf903a5793ad5f3ae9d06f085f4 made in Stein.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/configuration/schedulers.html#imagepropertiesfilter
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/admin/useful-image-properties.html

Change-Id: I7d761dc269f8c12c4a76ba14201ccdd82a04d01d
Closes-Bug: #1837756

(7 comments)

> (7 comments)
 > 
 > I see this as a sensible feature to add. Requiring the port to be
 > created by a privileged user is definitely a must.
 > 
 > Aside from a router instance, in theory this could _also_ works
 > towards the possibility of setting up a DHCP instance.

1) I don't agree with needing elevated privileges to create these kind of ports. Actually we can create those ports within a project, with normal permissions. This port will have available only in the broadcast domain of the network assigned. It is a user's problem to assign and use correctly this port inside this network.

2) You are right about the dhcp: every time we update a port, the DHCP agent will force a "reload_allocations" action. And in the Linux DHCP implementation, the dnsmasq process is spawned again with an updated hosts file. But in this case, the hosts file won't be updated. The VM (host) port without IP address, has an empty list in "port.fixed_ips".'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-07-05 14:27:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 25733, 'date': '2019-07-05 14:59:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Boot a VM with an unaddressed port

Currently Nova only allows to boot a VM if all ports attached:
- Have an IP assigned.
- The IP allocation is deferred.

But Nova doesn't allow to spawn a VM with a port without an IP assigned.
However, some kind of applications (e.g.: routers) need a port which may
be receiving traffic for several addresses, already configured in other
devices.

At the moment, Neutron permits to create a port, assigned to a network
with the corresponding subnetworks and IP pools, without an IP.

bp boot-vm-with-unaddressed-port

Change-Id: I48c7ddab4dae201530231d9061f2ade0aa600c07

commit_message:
Ensure tunnel types are absent if not configured

This patch fixes a bug where updating a configuration wouldn't remove
agent/tunnel_types configuration when required.

Conflicts:
  spec/classes/neutron_agents_ml2_ovs_spec.rb

Change-Id: I8248ad80e6ff88aec252919fa687018bda78a60b
Closes-Bug: #1832251
(cherry picked from commit 6c34ce2a42ae8c445a1fbe14ab18d4ee59e09c9b)

commit_message:
compute: Use source_bdms to reset attachment_ids during LM rollback

As we now provide the original source bdms during rollback we can also
use them to reset any volume attachment ids to the ids used by the
source compute host.

Change-Id: Ibe9215c07a1ee00e0e121c69bcf7ee1b1b80fae0

The two generic job failures [2] [3] are not a function of the change from running under python 2 to python 3.

We can take up the best way to address the second tempest run in the dummy job when we convert that legacy job to zuulv3.

Add py2 dummy jobs to keep some python 2 coverage through the

commit_message:
Run tempest jobs under python3

Add py2 dummy jobs to keep some python 2 coverage through the
Train release, but convert all the other tempest jobs to python 3.

Change-Id: Ia5fd26c30c6aaeb97ae1b524c5fd58b890fdb054

http://logs.openstack.org/94/668294/2/check/build-reno-releasenotes/a444cc9/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-07-03_22_52_54_297363'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-07-04 15:41:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-07-04 20:13:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-07-04 20:22:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Kevin,

Molecule supports [1] 'molecule converge -- --skip-tags'. Do you know how I can use it when molecule is run by CI?

Thanks,
  John

[1] https://molecule.readthedocs.io/en/stable/usage.html#converge

PS more detail:

When molecule runs tripleo-ceph-run-ansible and tripleo-ceph-uuid I want it to use --skip-tags run_ceph_ansible,run_uuid_ansible because we're not going to be able to install ceph inside the molecule containers. It's out of scope and these roles can be verified on if they _prepared_ correct to run ceph-ansible, not actually run ceph-ansible (scenario001 is already doing that fine). So certain tasks are tagged so that ansible doesn't actually run ceph-ansible for testing purposes. How can I use those tags when molecule tests these roles."}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-07-05 15:52:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Molecule supports [1] 'molecule converge -- --skip-tags'. Do you
 > know how I can use it when molecule is run by CI?

I'll try using this:

commit_message:
Add molecule test structure to ceph roles

Add molecule test structure for each ceph role. Also
add missing doc/*tripleo-ceph-*.rst files.

Local test setup changes have been made in support of
these roles.

Change-Id: I43b828d5c892a0b33c7a3cbae4034267ce493dc0
Task: 34717
Task: 34718
Task: 34719
Task: 34720
Story: 2006041
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

Add Python 3 Train unit tests

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-17 19:19:06.000000000', 'message': "Avoid using nova volume test data for cinder API mocking

self.volumes from nova test data is used as return values
of cinder API wrapper mock. Nova test data is based on
novaclient.v2.volumes.Volume class. This is not correct.
They should be based on cinderclient Volume class.

This commit changes to use cinder test data for
return values of openstack_dashboard.api.cinder mock.
'bootable' attribute is required, so it is added to cinder_data.

This confusion comes from the naming of self.volumes.
This commit renames self.volumes to self.nova_volumes
to avoid further confusions.

Note that api.nova.instance_volumes_list() calls get_server_volumes
from novaclient and it is correct to use self.nova_volumes.

Change-Id: I9c431dbb03f90bab84a4a6a3e3ea8fd5a5498b5b
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid using nova volume test data for cinder API mocking

self.volumes from nova test data is used as return values
of cinder API wrapper mock. Nova test data is based on
novaclient.v2.volumes.Volume class. This is not correct.
They should be based on cinderclient Volume class.

This commit changes to use cinder test data for
return values of openstack_dashboard.api.cinder mock.
'bootable' attribute is required, so it is added to cinder_data.

This confusion comes from the naming of self.volumes.
This commit renames self.volumes to self.nova_volumes
to avoid further confusions.

Note that api.nova.instance_volumes_list() calls get_server_volumes
from novaclient and it is correct to use self.nova_volumes.

Change-Id: I9c431dbb03f90bab84a4a6a3e3ea8fd5a5498b5b

commit_message:
Add kolla-ansible to zuul job dependencies

This means we can pull in the job from other repositories without
explicitly adding the dependency on kolla-ansible in that project.

Change-Id: Ia7e4294508e6d445638c176359a939af32fdfb12

commit_message:
devstack: do not use configure_auth_token_middleware

The devstack function configure_auth_token_middleware is deprecated,
because it specifies an option (signing_dir) which has been removed
a few releases ago.
Use the new configure_keystone_token_middleware function, which does
not use the removed parameter. Remove also all the logic related
to that parameter.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/628651
Change-Id: Ic13d8cfb3aeb425a7ad28ec1b8fc95629fafcc2f

commit_message:
py3: use the train test template and other updates

Use the unified unit test Zuul template for train, according the
community goal. Also, update the setup.cfg classifiers accordingly.

Update the debug test environment. Adding "debug-py36" is enough;
if a distribution supports 3.7, the "debug" tox environment
can be used.

Finally, keep only the most recent environment in the default
set executed when calling tox.

Story: #2005924
Task: #34244

Change-Id: Iad4a6e933ad416eb67a2f144540fe79e97938bec

commit_message:
Image deletion returns 500 if 'file' store is not enabled

When image import fails during image is uploading from staging area,
image remains in uploading state and data remains in staging area. In
this scenario if 'file' store is not enabled then while deleting the
image glance-api returns 500 status code with error 'file' scheme is
Unknwon.

Used os module to unlink the file present in staging area explicitly to
delete the data from staging area.

Change-Id: I57dcd6b18b0039e824e8adbe77de59079360a34f
Closes-Bug: #1836140

commit_message:
Use password as fallback option during SSH to instance

As we have some known issues with configuring ssh key on
the instance using metadata service (see related bugs) maybe
using password as fallback authentication method while
ssh to the cirros based vms will help to make our CI jobs more
green.

commit_message:
Use password as fallback option during SSH to instance

As we have some known issues with configuring ssh key on
the instance using metadata service (see related bugs) maybe
using password as fallback authentication method while
ssh to the cirros based vms will help to make our CI jobs more
green.

Change-Id: I04c4e63442f22ffe90062c007f5920be63855f2f
Related-Bug: #1821912
Related-Bug: #1836642

commit_message:
Nova: Update Cell management to allow db updates and improve rabbit

This PS allows the db connection string for the singular cell that OSH
currently supports to be updated, and also uses the full connection
string for the transport url.

Change-Id: I700133263273e04dad5b3e69d5e1f8255323e560
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-23 15:50:06.000000000', 'message': "stein: install python3-mysqldb for sqlalchemy dialect change

At Stein, the default mysql dialect in SQLAlchemy switched back
to MySQLDB in Ubuntu; as a result the db connection URL's stored
in the nova_api database for Nova cells are stale and need to
prefixed mysql+pymysql:// to work with the pymysql dialect.

However at this point in time there is no way to update the DB
URL for Nova Cell 0.

This fix works around this problem by installing python3-mysqldb
which provides the default dialect needed when using mysql://
prefixed DB connection URI's.

Change-Id: I3f74f18f649786fefa113fc3d8fa7c24010a185d
Related-Bug: 1835037
"}]
commit_message:
stein: install python3-mysqldb for sqlalchemy dialect change

At Stein, the default mysql dialect in SQLAlchemy switched back
to MySQLDB in Ubuntu; as a result the db connection URL's stored
in the nova_api database for Nova cells are stale and need to
prefixed mysql+pymysql:// to work with the pymysql dialect.

However at this point in time there is no way to update the DB
URL for Nova Cell 0.

This fix works around this problem by installing python3-mysqldb
which provides the default dialect needed when using mysql://
prefixed DB connection URI's.

Change-Id: I3f74f18f649786fefa113fc3d8fa7c24010a185d
Related-Bug: 1835037

commit_message:
Disambiguate logs in delete_allocation_for_instance

Two different error conditions in
SchedulerReportClient.delete_allocation_for_instance printed the same
warning log, which could be confusing. Reword one of them to
disambiguate.

Change-Id: Id1c5493a7270f2d0594e918df8704f671416a221

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-27872 : FAILURE in 1h 02m 01s'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-03-04 11:53:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-03-04 20:30:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

-1 because it's not clear to me what console type CONF.my_ip is for (needs a code comment please).

Also, I wonder if it's really worth the extra work (the TODOs) to determine the myriad of console hostnames from each driver and console type in the special cases. That is, I wonder if instead of doing this by host, if we should instead do it without a host filter (any expired) and just do them in batches, similar to how the _heal_instance_info_cache periodic task works.

I'd like to get opinions from others first."}, {'account_id': 7634, 'date': '2019-03-08 01:01:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7634, 'date': '2019-03-08 01:03:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-19 07:38:45.000000000', 'message': "Fix cleaning up console tokens

The periodic task to clean up expired console_auth tokens
does not work properly because there are cases that
'host' in the 'console_auth_tokens' table is different from
hosts where nova-compute processes run.

This patch fixes cases that host in the table is
one of configuration option values.

The subsequent patch will fix other cases.

Change-Id: I61cee4245e612b4bef1ffaacc634a8302cf836e9
Partial-Bug: #1816399

commit_message:
Fix cleaning up console tokens

The periodic task to clean up expired console_auth tokens
does not work properly because there are cases that 'host'
in the 'console_auth_tokens' table is different from
hosts where nova-compute processes run.

So make the periodic task to clear all expired console tokens
regardless of hosts where nova-compute processes run.

Change-Id: I61cee4245e612b4bef1ffaacc634a8302cf836e9
Closes-Bug: #1816399

commit_message:
Consts for need_healing

Followup for [1], this creates private module-level constants for the
``need_healing`` toggle used in the code, indicating whether the
allocations need to be healed by creating them or by updating existing
allocations.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/668925/7/nova/cmd/manage.py@2069

Change-Id: I60f251cf76eeb7ec0953ad085f3606b0edf5535c

commit_message:
do not set INFLUXDB_VERSION

influxdb was updated to 1.7.6[1].

Also we are using python version of monasca-api and 0.9.5 is needed for
java version.
So removing this default to let monasca-api handle the variables value

1 - I14f441f5fee46fa273bc4ea1d57662c2e4ac60c2

Change-Id: Ie61fac97b10ce6bf3a9eaf078d8ab10030e6d8a2

This patch propose to release new version of neutron-tempest-plugin
(version 0.4.0) as it has some important fixes, like [1] which aren't
included in e.g. 0.3.0 version and having new release with this patch
will help packaging projects (like RDO).

Change-Id: If4aa87189b00d1fab32841f1f05a66e6c69a852f
"}]
commit_message:
Release new version of neutron-tempest-plugin

This patch propose to release new version of neutron-tempest-plugin
(version 0.4.0) as it has some important fixes, like [1] which aren't
included in e.g. 0.3.0 version and having new release with this patch
will help packaging projects (like RDO).
It also switches back release model of neutron-tempest-plugin from
'cycly-automatic' to 'cycle-with-intermediary'.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/619207/

Change-Id: If4aa87189b00d1fab32841f1f05a66e6c69a852f

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-13 04:51:06.000000000', 'message': "[libvirt] Avoid create swap definition in xml

when resize instance, it's possible that resize from
flavor with swap to flavor without swap, this leaves
disk_mapping has swap defintion while the target instance's
swap is 0; if we don't do check , we will create defintion
in xml file but no disk exists on the host and lead to error.

Not sure this is right fix so will add UT later on

Change-Id: Iea1e25ce8364353634de91274756fcbb94c4fdb8
Closes-Bug: 1762423
"}]
commit_message:
[libvirt] Avoid create swap definition in xml

when resize instance, it's possible that resize from
flavor with swap to flavor without swap, this leaves
disk_mapping has swap defintion while the target instance's
swap is 0; if we don't do check , we will create defintion
in xml file but no disk exists on the host and lead to error.

Not sure this is right fix so will add UT later on

Change-Id: Iea1e25ce8364353634de91274756fcbb94c4fdb8
Closes-Bug: 1762423

commit_message:
Remove super old unnecessary TODO from API start() method

The ec2 API is not in tree nor does the start instance flow
deal with injected files or availability zones so remove the
really old TODO from when the API method was added in 2011.

Change-Id: I2df5010f50c032ae57adb2d128824a05a9189f9d

commit_message:
Remove usage of unix timestamps

This removes usage of unix timestamps in the codebase. They're replaced by
datetime objects. This is part of a larger effort aiming at making cloudkitty
timezone-aware. Timezone information will be added to the datetime objects
in another patch.

Change-Id: I7aadc314ceb5e36277bb51f55065ef558f10a7f2
Story: 2005319
Task: 30235

commit_message:
Allow for skipping custom env.d file checks

Currently if the env.d check fails and halts the upgrade, re-running
the run-upgrade.sh script doesn't pass the skip-tags flag to
Ansible.  This prompts the user to set the env variable if they want
to further skip checks and then passes the skip-tags as necessary.

Change-Id: Ic62887c7d8faa6a7a95021c012b1bf4f733edc33

subject: Leverage compression hardware accelerator
messages:
[{'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-04-14 11:42:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-04-14 11:54:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2019-04-15 14:16:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-04-16 02:05:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6491, 'date': '2019-05-03 15:46:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-07-03 09:42:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-07-03 09:42:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-07-09 07:31:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-07-10 12:57:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

I have some questions inline.

You're going to have to convince the glance team to add a new container_format or disk_format for this.  You are thinking of it as a new disk_format for cinder volumes, but another way to think of it is as a new  container_format that will contain a raw-format image file when Cinder uploads an image, but could also contain other image formats for other purposes.  (My personal opinion is that this makes more sense as a container_format, but I'm open to hearing contrary views.)"}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2019-07-10 16:46:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2019-07-10 17:06:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Need to understand what happens w/ Ceph, NFS, etc backends'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-07-12 03:42:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-07-12 03:49:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

@Eric Regarding Ceph, NFS, we setup these two as backend storage in our environment, took a test. These two has no difference in image conversion. 

Some Logs
-----------------
ceph: qemu-img convert -O qcow2 /opt/stack/data/cinder/conversion/volume-a09964ce-6c33-49c3-bdd9-9b72beea8dbf-73f66bee-1a7b-498f-8ea0-3a3afca730d9 /opt/stack/data/cinder/conversion/tmpiZIyvb

NFS:qzip -k /opt/stack/data/cinder/mnt/954b712a131a8f984fda77e5bf4d6c10/volume-38db9371-7879-4c50-b31a-46782f1e763d -o /opt/stack/data/cinder/conversion/tmpd91TTd

The volumes will be mounted to /opt/stack/data/cinder/… as a normal file(ceph) or blockfile(NFS). These are all supported.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-07-12 08:18:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2019-07-17 16:42:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2019-07-17 18:16:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

Mostly looks good.  A few wording things and a few suggestions for additional content.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-07-17 21:10:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

The original intent of this spec was to take advantage of a hardware accelerator if one exists, but after discussion, it's changed to something like: support upload of compressed volume-images to glance (because if there's no accelerator, we'll fall back to software compression).  What I'm getting at, is the original proposal would fail image creation if a compressed image was requested but a hardware accelerator is not present.  Now, image creation will succeed even if there's no accelerator, and this may be undesirable with respect to CPU load.

My question is: do we want to add a config option, something like allow_compression_on_image_upload, to control this (similar to what Eric is doing on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/668943/)?  Another possibility is that operators could control this by removing 'gz' from the allowable container formats on the Glance side (it's controlled by a config option).

My request here is to address this issue either in the Proposed Change section (if adding a config option is a good idea) or in the Alternatives section if this is something we don't want to do."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-07-17 21:11:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

One other thing -- are there any incompatibilities between https://review.opendev.org/#/c/668943/ and this proposal?'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-07-17 21:25:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-07-18 07:59:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(10 comments)

@rosmaita I think if user don't want compress the image, they can just select container_format as bare, then no compression will happen. So it seems we don't need the option "allow_compression_on_image_upload". This is different with Eric's solution where user would have no choice if without the option, the target disk format would always be qcow2.

This spec will not have any incompatibilities with Eric solution. Eric's solution is compression inside qcow2 format, after compressed, the disk format is still qcow2, this is transparent to outside world, and is disk format level. Just like we enabled the compression option in some filesystem such as btrfs, user can open/read/write files as usual, it's transparent to filesystem users. This spec is container format level. User may can group like these ways:

container_format: compressed, disk_format: qcow2(can be in compressed or not) If qcow2 in compressed, then it would be no benefit to select container_format also as compressed.

container_format: compressed disk_format: raw. This is the ideal choice'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-07-18 08:12:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-07-18 08:38:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Eric About NFS with snapshot, we did test and it works well with compression.

When uploading, the procedure is:
1. First use .info file to merge all changes (merge all snapshots and base volume to create a complete volume), this process will source the .info file in dir, e.g. /opt/stack/data/cinder/mnt/954b712a131a8f984fda77e5bf4d6c10. The cmd is like:

qemu-img convert -O raw /opt/stack/data/cinder/mnt/954b712a131a8f984fda77e5bf4d6c10/volume-0635fa23-9ce9-46d6-b178-bd0993fb5398.7c228ff3-5ba1-4c55-8b33-04f15724a3ce /opt/stack/data/cinder/conversion/0635fa23-9ce9-46d6-b178-bd0993fb5398.temp_image.ef76f39d-531a-4eb5-a2dd-35f28bcb2ac2rkNgzN.img

2. Compress the merged volume. e.g.
qzip -k /opt/stack/data/cinder/conversion/0635fa23-9ce9-46d6-b178-bd0993fb5398.temp_image.ef76f39d-531a-4eb5-a2dd-35f28bcb2ac2rkNgzN.img -o /opt/stack/data/cinder/conversion/tmprR3uPD'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-07-18 13:22:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

> @rosmaita I think if user don't want compress the image, they can just select container_format as bare, then no compression will happen. So it seems we don't need the option "allow_compression_on_image_upload".

Sorry I wasn't clear.  The problem is that the user may very well want to use compression, but the *operator* may not want to allow this because of the performance impact on the cinder nodes.  (This is a problem because the spec is now specifying software fallback for compression/decompression.)  So I think we need to seriously consider whether this should be configurable or not.  If you think it should be configurable, please add to "Proposed Change" section; if you disagree, please explain in the "Alternatives" section.

Thanks for the analysis of compatibility with Eric's qcow2 compression patch.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-07-19 04:01:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(6 comments)

@rosmaita I get your point of adding an option to control enable/disable compression now. It makes sense. Thanks'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-07-19 04:04:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-07-23 19:31:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

All my concerns have been addressed.  This looks worth doing.'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2019-07-24 15:27:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

My issues have been addressed and I think this is a good solution.  Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 6491, 'date': '2019-07-25 12:53:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Looks good.'}]

commit_message:
Leverage compression hardware accelerator

This spec proposes to leverage hardware compression accelerator to accelerate:
1) Image compression when uploading volume to glance as image.
2) Image decompression when creating volume from image

Change-Id: Ia9961f24c4ce78eec61601bd8308868a31a673d6
Signed-off-by: Liang Fang <liang.a.fang@intel.com>

commit_message:
Define default settings explicitly (openstack_dashboard 5/5)

This commit mainly covers settings in the remaining files
under openstack_dashboard.

Note that HORIZON_CONFIG, horizon and openstack_auth are not covered.
They will be covered by follow-up patches.

Part of blueprint ini-based-configuration
Change-Id: Ibd70e030445a073d9a62da9867850f4893135a89

subject: Switch python3 versions of test jobs to match Train PTI
messages:
[{'account_id': 30618, 'date': '2019-06-24 10:32:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-06-24 10:32:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

commit_message:
Switch python3 versions of test jobs to match Train PTI

In Train, we will use python 3.6 and 3.7 for python3 runtime
in our gate jobs [1]. This commit also adds python 3.7.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I3feb2652470606ace2a5ea13faeff58121bd085d

[{'created': '2019-07-15 18:54:57.000000000', 'message': "CI: clean up requirements installation

We install kolla-ansible requirements in Zuul's Ansible playbooks.
This patch cleans up the installation in scripts so that they are
only concerned with auxiliary requirements:
- ansible (since we do not track it in requirements)
- ara (for log summaries)
- openstack clients (for first init and tests after deployment)

Additionally this patch installs openstack clients in a separate
virtualenv.
Note that all kolla-ansible requirements, ansible and ara are still
installed system-wide.

Change-Id: Iac04082ad39a9d823c515ba11c5db9af50ed225f
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>

commit_message:
CI: clean up requirements installation

We install kolla-ansible requirements in Zuul's Ansible playbooks.
This patch cleans up the installation in scripts so that they are
only concerned with auxiliary requirements:
- ansible (since we do not track it in requirements)
- ara (for log summaries)
- openstack clients (for first init and tests after deployment)

Additionally this patch installs openstack clients in a separate
virtualenv.
Note that all kolla-ansible requirements, ansible and ara are still
installed system-wide.

Change-Id: Iac04082ad39a9d823c515ba11c5db9af50ed225f
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>

Comparing different VMs is a fools errand, but this might have made some difference in nested situations. Compare:

(1 comment)

Yeah, I like the defensive approach of calling .clear() in all the places, and the additional documentation.

All of my gripes have been addressed, except the DRYing of the lookup methods, which we've agreed can be done in a subsequent patch.

While a sample size of two results on different clouds isn't conclusive, it at least provides some assurance that we didn't make performance significantly *worse*, which, considering the added code consistency and prettiness, is good enough for me."}, {'account_id': 7634, 'date': '2019-07-25 03:18:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-23 14:25:12.000000000', 'message': "Make a TraitCache similar to ResourceClassCache

The Trait and ResourceClass db objects have the same essential
structure and are used throughout the code in similar ways:

* turn a name into an id
* turn an id into a name
* get an unfiltered list of names
* make a mapping of ids to names

In I409a5e819a72d64e66ee390e4528da0c503d8d05 we made the resource
class cache request specific. Doing that work made it pretty clear
we could have a similar cache for traits and as a result visit the
traits db fewer times per request.

Testing will be required to determine if this has any impact (positive
or negative) and this large patch could be broken into smaller pieces
but I wanted to get some early feedback (from humans and zuul).

The implementation is straightforward: make an AttributeCache super
class that is a parent to ResourceClassCache. Create TraitCache as
a sibling. The sole difference is the table used for the data authority
and the exception raised when an attribute is not found.

A 'get_all' method is added to the cache to list the full collection
of dicts it contains. That can be be directly transformed into Trait
and ResourceClass objects.

From the API, listing traits and resource classes (without filters) now
uses the cache instead of going to the db. Where filters (in traits) are
required, the db is accessed.

The research_context turns lists of trait names into id, name maps for
required and forbidden traits.

Further, anywhere the traits table was joined to create a name of an id,
the cache is used instead. This allows to drop some joins and operate
fully in-process and in-RAM. No additional loops are added to make this
happen: the translation is done in existing loops.

The upshot of these changes is that unless there is a write operation on
a trait or resource class, both tables are scanned at most once in any
request. And when they are scanned it is to list their entire contents.

Change-Id: Ia19ea2b4ecdde25323579edf60ad6269d05e75a2
"}, {'created': '2019-07-23 17:44:46.000000000', 'message': "Make a TraitCache similar to ResourceClassCache

The Trait and ResourceClass db objects have the same essential
structure and are used throughout the code in similar ways:

* turn a name into an id
* turn an id into a name
* get an unfiltered list of names
* make a mapping of ids to names

In I409a5e819a72d64e66ee390e4528da0c503d8d05 we made the resource
class cache request specific. Doing that work made it pretty clear
we could have a similar cache for traits and as a result visit the
traits db fewer times per request.

The implementation is straightforward: make an AttributeCache super
class that is a parent to ResourceClassCache. Create TraitCache as
a sibling. The sole difference is the table used for the data authority
and the exception raised when an attribute is not found.

The new super class has been refactored to use private attributes and
methods.

A 'get_all' method is added to the cache to list the full collection
of dicts it contains. That can be be directly transformed into Trait
and ResourceClass objects. The order of the results of this method
are not predictable, and sorting them would add cost for no benefit,
so gabbi tests which had previously relied on the ordered of returned
resource classes have been removed.

From the API, listing traits and resource classes (without filters) now
uses the cache instead of going to the db. Where filters (in traits) are
required, the db is accessed.

The research_context turns lists of trait names into id, name maps for
required and forbidden traits.

Further, anywhere the traits table was joined to create a name of an id,
the cache is used instead. This allows to drop some joins and operate
fully in-process and in-RAM. No additional loops are added to make this
happen: the translation is done in existing loops.

The upshot of these changes is that unless there is a write operation on
a trait or resource class, both tables are scanned at most once in any
request. And when they are scanned it is to list their entire contents.

Change-Id: Ia19ea2b4ecdde25323579edf60ad6269d05e75a2
"}, {'created': '2019-07-24 10:27:39.000000000', 'message': "Make a TraitCache similar to ResourceClassCache

The Trait and ResourceClass db objects have the same essential
structure and are used throughout the code in similar ways:

* turn a name into an id
* turn an id into a name
* get an unfiltered list of names
* make a mapping of ids to names

In I409a5e819a72d64e66ee390e4528da0c503d8d05 we made the resource
class cache request specific. Doing that work made it pretty clear
we could have a similar cache for traits and as a result visit the
traits db fewer times per request.

The implementation is straightforward: make an _AttributeCache super
class that is a parent to ResourceClassCache. Create TraitCache as
a sibling. The sole difference is the table used for the data authority
and the exception raised when an attribute is not found.

The new super class has been refactored to use private attributes and
methods.

A 'get_all' method is added to the cache to list the full collection
of dicts it contains. That can be be directly transformed into Trait
and ResourceClass objects. The order of the results of this method
are not predictable, and sorting them would add cost for no benefit,
so gabbi tests which had previously relied on the ordered of returned
resource classes have been removed.

From the API, listing traits and resource classes (without filters) now
uses the cache instead of going to the db. Where filters (in traits) are
required, the db is accessed.

The research_context turns lists of trait names into id, name maps for
required and forbidden traits.

Further, anywhere the traits table was joined to create a name of an id,
the cache is used instead. This allows to drop some joins and operate
fully in-process and in-RAM. No additional loops are added to make this
happen: the translation is done in existing loops.

The upshot of these changes is that unless there is a write operation on
a trait or resource class, both tables are scanned at most once in any
request. And when they are scanned it is to list their entire contents.

As noted in the _AttributeCache docstring there are restrictions
on what kinds of entities can use the cache and some necessary
precautions.

Change-Id: Ia19ea2b4ecdde25323579edf60ad6269d05e75a2
"}]
commit_message:
Make a TraitCache similar to ResourceClassCache

The Trait and ResourceClass db objects have the same essential
structure and are used throughout the code in similar ways:

* turn a name into an id
* turn an id into a name
* get an unfiltered list of names
* make a mapping of ids to names

In I409a5e819a72d64e66ee390e4528da0c503d8d05 we made the resource
class cache request specific. Doing that work made it pretty clear
we could have a similar cache for traits and as a result visit the
traits db fewer times per request.

The implementation is straightforward: make an _AttributeCache super
class that is a parent to ResourceClassCache. Create TraitCache as
a sibling. The sole difference is the table used for the data authority
and the exception raised when an attribute is not found.

The new super class has been refactored to use private attributes and
methods.

A 'get_all' method is added to the cache to list the full collection
of dicts it contains. That can be be directly transformed into Trait
and ResourceClass objects. The order of the results of this method
are not predictable, and sorting them would add cost for no benefit,
so gabbi tests which had previously relied on the ordered of returned
resource classes have been removed.

From the API, listing traits and resource classes (without filters) now
uses the cache instead of going to the db. Where filters (in traits) are
required, the db is accessed.

The research_context turns lists of trait names into id, name maps for
required and forbidden traits.

Further, anywhere the traits table was joined to create a name of an id,
the cache is used instead. This allows to drop some joins and operate
fully in-process and in-RAM. No additional loops are added to make this
happen: the translation is done in existing loops.

The upshot of these changes is that unless there is a write operation on
a trait or resource class, both tables are scanned at most once in any
request. And when they are scanned it is to list their entire contents.

As noted in the _AttributeCache docstring there are restrictions
on what kinds of entities can use the cache and some necessary
precautions.

Change-Id: Ia19ea2b4ecdde25323579edf60ad6269d05e75a2

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-22 12:52:44.000000000', 'message': 'Update all columns in metrics on an update to refresh TTL

Cassandra Time to Live (TTL) is applied per-column in a
row, and with a default TTL for the table.  The Cassandra
driver appears to have been written with a misunderstanding
that the TTL was per-row, and as a result the update
statements were written to avoid writing all cells.
But that results in some cells in the row not being updated,
and after their TTL expires they are removed, so a metric
query may result in partial data (updated_at set but
metric_id and created_at missing).

This fix changes the statement used when a new measurement
is received to use the same insert statement for the metric
row and thus refresh the TTL for all the columns.

A follow on patch should be created to remove the Update
statements for Measurements, and consider refactoring/removing
the caching model.

Change-Id: I6b7636a52e8bdb2ce8ad97f839acb6184cd58a8b
Story: 2005832
Task: 35872
'}]
commit_message:
Update all columns in metrics on an update to refresh TTL

Cassandra Time to Live (TTL) is applied per-column in a
row, and with a default TTL for the table.  The Cassandra
driver appears to have been written with a misunderstanding
that the TTL was per-row, and as a result the update
statements were written to avoid writing all cells.
But that results in some cells in the row not being updated,
and after their TTL expires they are removed, so a metric
query may result in partial data (updated_at set but
metric_id and created_at missing).

This fix changes the statement used when a new measurement
is received to use the same insert statement for the metric
row and thus refresh the TTL for all the columns.

A follow on patch should be created to remove the Update
statements for Measurements, and consider refactoring/removing
the caching model.

Change-Id: I6b7636a52e8bdb2ce8ad97f839acb6184cd58a8b
Story: 2005832
Task: 35872

commit_message:
Pass extra_specs to flavor in vif tests

Outside the test environment, extra_specs is usually present, even if
empty.

Although it doesn't cause test failures right now, it is fixed just
in case it might in the future.

Change-Id: I8ca6f0f37a18f81d024286a0e158353ed25fa2b5
